      • clone

        public SingleVariablePropositionalConstraint clone()

      • destructiveUpdateOrNullAfterConjoiningNewNormalizedAtom

        public AbstractSingleVariableConstraint destructiveUpdateOrNullAfterConjoiningNewNormalizedAtom(boolean sign,
                                                                                                Expression atom,
                                                                                                Context context)
        Description copied from class: AbstractSingleVariableConstraint
        Extending classes define this method to perform whatever checks are needed after a new atom has been inserted, returning null in case of a detected contradiction or this object, or a simplified version of it, otherwise.

        In general, this will contain whatever theory-specific checks and simplifications that go beyond simple contradiction between normalized atoms.

        One example of this method being useful is in equality theory with finite domains. If a variable is constrained to be disequal to n distinct values and its type size is equal or less than n, we know the constraint is unsatisfiable. Because AbstractSingleVariableConstraint knows nothing about equalities, it will not detect that. An extension defining equality constraints can define this method to perform such check.

        Specified by:
        destructiveUpdateOrNullAfterConjoiningNewNormalizedAtom in class AbstractSingleVariableConstraint
        Returns:

      • fromNormalizedAtomToItsNegationAsLiteral

        public Expression fromNormalizedAtomToItsNegationAsLiteral(Expression negativeAtom)
        Description copied from class: AbstractSingleVariableConstraint
        Returns the literal corresponding to the negation of the given normalized atom. Typically this will just return the application of NOT to the atom, but some languages may have more conventional (and more pleasing to read) ways of representing these negations (for example, not(X = a) -> X != a).
        Specified by:
        fromNormalizedAtomToItsNegationAsLiteral in class AbstractSingleVariableConstraint
        Returns:

      • fromLiteralOnVariableToSignAndNormalizedAtom

        public Pair<java.lang.Boolean,Expression> fromLiteralOnVariableToSignAndNormalizedAtom(Expression variable,
                                                                                       Expression literal,
                                                                                       Context context)
        Description copied from class: AbstractSingleVariableConstraint
        Defines how a literal is decomposed into sign and atom. Atom representations should be normalized (equivalent atoms should always be represented by the same expressions). For example, X != a could be decomposed into false and X = a. Note that the notion of "atom" is internal to a single-variable constraint with a specific variable. Other constraints may produce different atoms from the same literals; for example, X = Y may be normalized into X = Y for a constraint on X, and to Y = X for a constraint on Y.
        Returns:

      • conjoin

        public SingleVariablePropositionalConstraint conjoin(Expression formula,
                                                     Context context)
        Description copied from interface: Constraint
        Returns an SGDPLLTTester representing the conjunction of this constraint and a given formula, or null if they are contradictory.

        At this point, the formula should be either a literal, or a Constraint.

        Extensions may want to override this method if there are more efficient ways of conjoining with (certain types of) constraints than simply treating them as a formula

        Parameters:
        formula - the formula to be conjoined.
        context - the context
        Returns:
        the application result or null if contradiction.

      • binding

        Description copied from interface: SingleVariableConstraint
        Returns an expression to which the constraint's variable is bound to under this constraint, if there is such a value and it can be determined by the implementation.
